Overall%20Experience.Review:
This course aims to help individuals understand how power works and how to develop influence within their organizations and society. The course is six weeks long and requires about 6-7 hours per week. The course includes six modules:

• Understanding the Nature of Power
• Building Relational Sources of Power
• Earning Trust and Exercising Influence
• Encountering Entrenched Power
• Leading Change in Organizations and Society
• Managing Your Relationship to Power

The course teaches individuals how to gain influence, make an impact, avoid the pitfalls of power, build networks, and assess an organization's political landscape. It also focuses on developing influence skills to shift power dynamics, exercising power ethically, and holding the powerful accountable. The course is beneficial for early- and mid-career professionals, aspiring entrepreneurs, and nonprofit leaders. Upon completion of the course, participants earn a Certificate of Completion from HBS Online

Overall%20Experience.Review:
Harvard University is one of the most prestigious and oldest institutions of higher learning in the world, located in Cambridge, Massachusetts. It is renowned for its rigorous academics, exceptional faculty, and a vibrant campus life. Here's an overview of the Harvard experience:

Academics

Harvard offers a wide range of undergraduate and graduate programs, spanning fields like arts, sciences, law, medicine, business, and more. The university emphasizes critical thinking, innovation, and research, providing students access to state-of-the-art facilities and resources.

Campus Life

The campus is rich in history and culture, featuring iconic landmarks like the Widener Library and Harvard Yard. Students participate in numerous extracurricular activities, including clubs, sports, and community service, fostering a well-rounded experience.

I loved the small, seminar-style classes where I could engage in deep discussions with my classmates - people from such diverse backgrounds who each brought unique perspectives to the table.

That said, Harvard wasn't without its challenges. The workload was intense, and I sometimes struggled to maintain a healthy work-life balance. The university could do more to support student mental health and wellbeing, like better access to counseling services, more wellness programming, etc.

But overall, my experience at Harvard was truly transformative. The knowledge and skills I gained have been invaluable, and the connections I made will continue to benefit me long after graduation.

Overall%20Experience.Review:
I like the way Harvard University makes education affordable for the poor.

Harvard costs what your family can afford. They make sure of that. If your family's income is less than $85,000, you'll pay nothing. For families who earn between $85,000 and $150,000, the expected contribution is between zero and ten percent of your annual income.

Harvard is more affordable than public universities for 90 percent of Americans—and international students receive the same financial aid as American students. Harvard makes sure that they have an affordable option for your education.

They follow two important principles:
1) Need-blind admissions. Your financial need and your aid application will never affect your chance of being admitted to Harvard.
2) 100% need-based aid. They base aid awards on need, not on merit. This means that financial aid supports the students who will benefit from it the most. Furthermore, they meet 100 percent of their student's demonstrated financial need.

Overall%20Experience.Review: From the moment I stepped onto campus, I've encountered one problem after another. The first and most significant issue is the rampant rat infestation, which has affected everything. These rodents run rampant, and it's impossible to get a good night's sleep with their incessant noise and fear of them crawling on you as you sleep. It's a constant battle to keep them out of your personal space. The food situation is equally dismal. The dining halls are plagued by unsanitary conditions, with rats scurrying around openly. It's impossible to enjoy a meal without worrying about contamination. The quality of the food itself is subpar. But perhaps the most disheartening aspect of my college experience is the teaching staff. I've had the misfortune of encountering a series of unqualified and disinterested professors. It's apparent that they lack the enthusiasm and expertise required to provide a quality education. Their disengagement only exacerbates the frustration and disappointment I feel.

If you're looking for top-notch education with a dash of fun and a sprinkle of diversity, Harvard's your place. The courses? Outstanding. From humanities to sciences, you've got a smorgasbord of choices led by seriously brilliant professors.

But the real magic of Harvard lies in the students. They're from all over the world, bringing a riot of perspectives that makes every class discussion buzz with energy. It's like a global village where you learn as much from your mates as your textbooks.

And it's not all study, either. There's plenty to do outside the lecture halls. Join a club, get sporty, or just hang out on the gorgeous campus - there's never a dull moment. Harvard's not just a university, it's a vibrant and stimulating experience.

The faculty are world-renowned experts in their fields and provide students with unparalleled opportunities to learn from and collaborate with them.

The residential system at Harvard is also a major part of the overall experience. Living in a House with other students from diverse backgrounds and interests allows for the formation of close-knit communities and lifelong friendships. These communities foster personal growth and intellectual exploration, as well as provide support and encouragement throughout one's time at Harvard.

Overall%20Experience.Review: In addition to its wealth, Harvard’s prestige derives from its research faculty and undergraduate success post graduation. Neither of these factors are indicators of education quality. For example, faculty are uninterested in teaching, so Harvard outsources the bulk of this work to underpaid lecturers or graduate students. On the other hand, undergraduate success is correlated with pre-existing class, racial, and gender hierarchies. Having graduated from Harvard and taught at several other universities (public and private), I am confident that many other places do it better. Harvard gets too much credit for what it does not do because, as others have said, it is a social club pretending to be a center of undergraduate learning. The curriculum fails to deliver a knowledge base across disciplines because it is too niche. Finally, the student body is less academically inclined than you might think because Harvard prioritizes the extracurricular achievements of the upper-middle class.

Overall%20Experience.Review: Some people have astronomical egos and believe that they're gods gift to the world because they got into Harvard; when in reality you find out that their good ol pops donated three buildings to the school. Food is okay I like the ramen shop but stay away from the pizza places near campus! I felt comfortable walking alone at night.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Sophomore

Overall%20Experience.Review: Great academics with a variety of concentrations, classes, and world-renowned professors. Great extracurricular life and the ability to network with alumni, staff, and other students to reach your goals career-wise. However, this institution falls flat when it comes to social life. This university runs on exclusivity, especially with final clubs which are honestly just fancy fraternities and sororities which run on exacerbating class and racial differences. Additionally, there is little support for marginalized communities from Harvard, with LGBT events getting very little traction. The social groups come across as very cliquish — if you don’t make friends fast, it is very hard to get into a social group and connect with other people so you may feel lonely. The dining hall food is lackluster while the dining hall hours and locations are abysmal. The housing concept is great, but there’s very little community in the houses which makes it hard to connect with other students. Overrated!
Overall%20Experience.Author: Junior

Overall%20Experience.Review: Harvard Campus is busy with tourists. No parking. All off campus students take public transport. Academics are as great as you can imagine. Despite what data says, 85% of the population by eye is White or Asian, in my opinion. Professors are incredible. I can not speak on ROI due to my tuition being ~$0. I also stay off campus. Public transportation is tolerable.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Sophomore

Overall%20Experience.Review: Harvard is a place where you can make the experience whatever you'd want it to be. Find your group, explore your passions, and be ready to go anywhere in the world after graduating.

There are reliable, frequent shuttles, and there are multiple apps for real-time schedules and routes! The campus itself is based in Cambridge, so it is relatively urban, but I always felt very secure.

Harvard is diverse and I hope you will meet nice people there even though i can't guarantee everyone is nice there.
However, concerning your academics, it might look tedious at the start but as you get more into it and make friends as well as an academic plan and a good schedule, you'll find out that its not as tiring as you felt it was.

Social life is not as prominent as it is at other schools because academics and athletics definitely dominate the  scene. Boston is definitely a college CITY. With so many colleges in a 10 mile radius you only see college study out and about. Overall a very eye opening experience, just make sure to visit and be sure that this is what you seek in your college experience!

Overall%20Experience.Review: There are endless opportunities for students at Harvard. I have made some of the greatest friendships with alumni, professors, and students. Overall%20Experience.Review:
I took an online course with Harvard Business School Online and it was an amazing experience for a former homeschooler.
I've only taken one course so far, but I wish to take several more in the near future.

Allowing anyone over the age of 18 and providing knowledge to anyone out of high-school, the course provided me with eye-opening and inspirational education early on in my life that I've been able to take with me to further my education, to work with, as well as to use at home. 

I loved the interactive learning experience, the short interviews with experts of several fields, and I most of all liked the case studies. 

I can't say there was anything I didn't like.. about the school itself. 
The only thing was some of the peer exercises. Some required students to interact with other students, and then to receive peer feedback. However, often times, I never did receive feedback.

Besides that, everything else was fantastic.

Overall%20Experience.Review:
I came to Harvard as an advanced graduate student after experiences ranging from the University of Washington to German Universities includin Freiburg in the Black Forest, Tübingen, and Münster.
Harvard distinguishes itself in the quality of fellow students, first, then a fine assortment of expert professors and a wondrous library and extensive museums.  Incoming students must plan their time carefully or risk missing one of the world's top cultural sites.  That said, a scholarly education is incomplete without experiences in other lands, where notions of team sports do not compete with university identities.  Find the best world-class professors in your areas of interest and go to them.  Stay as long as it takes to satisfy yourself.

Overall%20Experience.Review:
The academics here are top-notch and extracurriculars are all-around excellent, as you would expect of a place with Harvard's reputation. If you are looking for a party school, this is not the place for you - the scene is pretty standard for a large-sized American school and on the whole you are expected to work hard more than play hard. Students spend a lot of time networking and treat their clubs like full-time careers, and for good reason - they often secure job offers on the strengths of having well-known student groups and internships on their resumes. 

However, the school still needs to work on doing more than paying lip service to diversity. It has exceptional cultural diversity but doesn't do enough for its students who are low-income and black or Native American, for instance. The school's mental health efforts have also been largely misdirected.

Overall%20Experience.Review: The campus is beautiful there, everything was conveniently nearby: restaurants, beaches, malls, and of course, Boston. Student centers like the Smith Center or the Cabot Library in the Science Center are very helpful for study groups, or tutoring sessions with the reservable rooms available. Widener Library is also a very relaxing place to be in general. There was a wide range of diversity in people, personalities, experiences and expertise. Everyone is willing to help others and it is very easy to meet people. While the majority of the time the campus and the centers feel very safe, I constantly hear about incidents occurring mainly during night at certain areas close by. The professors there are very helpful, and the lessons tend to be interactive and actually enjoyable. Although the courses were extremely difficult, unlike anything I've ever experienced before, learning the information was fun although tedious.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Niche User

Overall%20Experience.Review: I went to Harvard University for two weeks in the summer at a debate camp, in which we learned national-level techniques for speech and debate. They taught us how to cross-examine, how to organize and format arguments, speech exercises, and research methods. It was profoundly informative. Furthermore, the professors were highly helpful and educated and the dorms were of decent quality, despite lacking air conditioning. The campus was quite beautiful, with vast fields of greenery and trees. We went to one party on the Fourth of July with amazing food and a wonderful friend atmosphere. The local area had high-quality restaurants with interesting, modern attractions. The campus food itself was suitable, but not excellent compared to the food sold at restaurants nearby.

Libraries and other campus resources are easily accessible, but it is difficult to get good vegetarian options during lunch and dinner at Annenberg Hall. Professors are very open and we had lots of excellent discussions over research they've done and books they've written, and it was the best summer of my entire life.

Overall%20Experience.Author: Niche User

Overall%20Experience.Review: I like Harvard very much because it is a great university and challenges me to learn more and stretch myself. Its academics are number one.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Freshman

Overall%20Experience.Review: What i liked was the environment. They have great professors that can really help you learn about your major. This is a great place to be . You wont regret coming here.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Junior

Overall%20Experience.Review: Harvard Square, Cambridge, and the Greater Boston Area is a great place to live and work. It's filled with diversity and excellent events and opportunities. Harvard faculty members are caring, and the dorms are comfortable to live in.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Works Here

Overall%20Experience.Review: Harvard is a place where education is approached from a different perspective as the university values learning and curiosity more than recognition. Students at Harvard are so genuinely passionate about learning that they're able to achieve a level of thinking that not many people can achieve, which is metacognition: thinking about your thinking or learning process. The interdisciplinary and collaborative environment, as well as the passionate friends I have made, have allowed me to unleash my curiosity and creativity. Harvard is not only a school for intellects, it is a school for passionate people. People work hard, are determined, and believe in what they do. The most beautiful aspect about Harvard is the fact that hierarchy is not relevant. Professors do not brag about their awards and degrees, graduate and undergraduate students work together, and everyone is open to help each other. Harvard is a beautiful and intellectually stimulating place to study.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Freshman

Overall%20Experience.Review: Prestigious. Knowledgeable staff. Smart students. Beautiful campus.  Dorm is old. Buildings are old.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Graduate Student

Overall%20Experience.Review: Harvard University is a great campus that's dedicated to teaching students how to change the world. Their general facilities, professors, and students, make it very easy to get connected with some of the best minds in the world. Harvard is a university that is truly top tier and the students who attend Harvard are some of the most dedicated and hard working individuals in this world. In addition, other living aspects of the college like the campus and extracurricular events like recreational sports, study groups, and organized parties are extremely fun and engaging. These events make it extremely easy to get plugged in and make lasting social relations.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Graduate Student

Overall%20Experience.Review: The university offers excellent tuition to students. The professors are good and very experienced.The dormitories have a lot of facilities to make one enjoy their stay on campus.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Niche User

Overall%20Experience.Review: Excellent resources and professors. The classes are kept to a small number of students and there is plenty of opportunity to share and to discuss topics in a more in-depth manner. Professors are available to meet with you and to help support your learning. The campus is full of events and the time you have with friends to discuss your learning is excellent.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Graduate Student

Overall%20Experience.Review: This university is without a doubt worth five stars. I would give the academics five stars.  I would give the return on investment five stars.  I would give the diversity five stars.  I would give the campus five stars.  I would give the athletics five stars.  I would give the party scene five stars.  I would give the professors five stars.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Niche User

Overall%20Experience.Review: Harvard has a great reputation. A degree from Harvard will certainly help my future career. Harvard has excellent Professors with multiple research opportunities. Harvard has almost unlimited resources.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Freshman

Overall%20Experience.Review: It is a great experience to interact with motivated, interesting people from all over the world. The classes are engaging and challenging.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Senior

Overall%20Experience.Review: It is a very beautiful and antique building that really brings students to enjoy their college life.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Niche User

Overall%20Experience.Review: It is Harvard. The education is not only excellent but also world known, by studying in a such an institute you will create connections with people all over the world.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Niche User

Overall%20Experience.Review: Great school with great traditions and academics. World renowned education that challenges the students
Overall%20Experience.Author: Graduate Student

Overall%20Experience.Review: Went on a 7 week Pre-collegiate course here and I fell in love instantly! Proud to say it was the  first college I've ever been too. Area is amazing and the diverse personalities from all walks of life has inspired me to raise my standards exponetially ever since. There's no place I'd rather be than back in Harvard Yard for my freshman year of college ! #GoCrimson
Overall%20Experience.Author: Niche User

Overall%20Experience.Review: I am attending Harvard for my premedical studies. The resources are great and extremely beneficial to my learning. The overall teaching is also amazing and the professors truly care about the students.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Graduate Student

Overall%20Experience.Review: I enjoyed the campus, it was very nice and clean. The people were very welcoming and helpful in finding places and stores around campus.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Niche User

Overall%20Experience.Review: some of the professors are very rude, but besides that everything else is okay the oly other thing is that they can work on getting better food for how much it cost to attend.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Graduate Student

Overall%20Experience.Review: Harvard should be the best when it comes to mental health and mental health issues among students yet it is clear there is a lack of training, understanding, and community that helps students who begin to struggle while they are at the university. Without catching students early it could impact a class grade. A student can not fail a class at Harvard without major consequences. There needs to be some or more training for advisers, deans, teaching fellows and professors to watch for students who start to withdraw and are having mental health issues.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Junior

Overall%20Experience.Review: Strong support system for its students. Embracing and diverse community of students. A place of boundless opportunities and chances to hire.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Freshman

Overall%20Experience.Review: Beautiful campus, diverse faculty and students, and great educational experience; both online and in-person.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Niche User

Overall%20Experience.Review: Though it took some time, Harvard came to be my home away from home and I loved my time there. From the academic diversity to the amazing students and faculty, there's so much to learn in just a few short years.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Alum

Overall%20Experience.Review: Harvard University has excellent programs for graduate students. The courses are flexible and fit around work schedules. However, the material can be challenging and very time consuming. I would recommend going to graduate school here.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Graduate Student

Overall%20Experience.Review: I loved the general campus feel. The academics were wide and diverse providing me an outlet for creative growth.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Niche User

Overall%20Experience.Review: The best university in the world, period. The quality of the people at Harvard from professors to your classmates is simply tremendous. Every day at Harvard is a learning experience from the best and brightest in the world. Harvard will give you a valuable opportunity to learn and grow as a human being while forging lifelong friendships with amazing people.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Alum

Overall%20Experience.Review: Interaction with intelligent people unbelievable.  Missing in other universities and areas.  The environment around HU is also very stimulating and a lot of interesting events going on.  Hard to bead
Overall%20Experience.Author: Works Here

Overall%20Experience.Review: Harvard has been amazing. Coming from Khartoum, Sudan, the shift to life in America was very drastic. Thankfully, Harvard was the ideal environment for me to acclimate myself to all the differences in lifestyle and academic rigor.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Sophomore

Overall%20Experience.Review: Harvard University gave me a lot of tools and skills to success in academic as well as my future career. I would definitely recommend it to anyone who come here to study. However, the classrooms are a little bit old and needed to remodel badly.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Alum

Overall%20Experience.Review: Harvard University is the best university one could get into for education due to the unmatched intellectual atmosphere consisting of the world's top brains with cutting edge research being done in all fields leading to new interdisciplinary collaborations.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Graduate Student

Overall%20Experience.Review: I had a hard time adjusting my first semester, but now I am looking forward to my next three years here. The weather is a bit terrible, but there are so many exciting things going on all the time!
Overall%20Experience.Author: Sophomore

Overall%20Experience.Review: Harvard University is an institution that is constantly reviewing and improving upon itself. Whether its the constant renovations, multiple opportunities for student voices to be heard, or the emphasis on academic areas that the school is not known for (i.e. STEM), Harvard is constantly working to EARN it's title as the number one Ivy, and one of the best universities in the world.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Sophomore

Overall%20Experience.Review: Great place.  Great academics. Great students.  Great professors.   All around great great.  Great.  Great.    Kk.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Alum

Overall%20Experience.Review: It's a prestigious university, but it isn't the school, it's the student. A college name is just a name, but everything else is developed through self-determination.
Overall%20Experience.Author: Niche User

Student%20Life.Review: Very diverse by race and location. It does seem to skew towards higher income levels but that has many reasons for being so.
Student%20Life.Author: College Senior

Student%20Life.Review: Don't really know that much about Greek Life here, for grad students it's a non-issue and doesn't seem overly important to students.
Student%20Life.Author: College Senior

Student%20Life.Review: The gyms and everything are pretty nice but nothing to write home about. Not as nice as I thought they'd be.
Student%20Life.Author: College Senior

Student%20Life.Review: Greek life isn't  a big part of the school.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: A surprising number of people are varsity athletes and are world class.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: The athletic opportunities are amazing. Just probe around and you'll find anything that suits you.
Student%20Life.Author: College Senior

Student%20Life.Review: Eh. Harvard is not known for its Greek life.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: I think that Harvard is very subtle in its adoration for sports. It has the most division I NCAA teams of any school in the country, but you'd hardly know it from the outside looking in.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: The teams are great, fans not so much.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: Under a lot of flack lately. Very controversial recently.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: Good athletics program with some great sports teams. School spirit is not too high, except during Harvard-Yale.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: Not really a big deal on campus.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: We have some surprisingly good teams, but the majority of the student population could care less about any sports.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: i don't really know. but i think i shouldn't create significant troubles
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: the school has variety of clubs that you can utilize and develop your interest in sports on a deeper level
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: I don't participate in Greek life so I don't really know, but it seems like a nice group of people for whom it's not a huge deal but adds if you're seeking that out.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: The facilities are good for both athletes and students, but no one really cares about varsity sports unless it's the Harvard-Yale game.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: Some facilities are great while some are mediocre.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: I love the club sports, but club sports like cheerleading are underfunded.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: I play soccer for my school and I have fun with my friends through practicing soccer together.
Student%20Life.Author: College Student

Student%20Life.Review: Harvard targets and hits specific %s.
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: Final Clubs are way more important.
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: No one really cares about them but I love going to games.
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: greatest athletic facilities in the world
Student%20Life.Author: College Student

Student%20Life.Review: Everyone can go to the parties, if they're interested
Student%20Life.Author: Recent Alumnus

Student%20Life.Review: Not much variety in terms of sororities, there are few black sororities and fraternities which is sad. Harvard isn't doing anything about this even after it has been brought to their attention MANY times, and that's even worse.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: Frats at Harvard are different—not snobby, overly fratty, or obnoxious. Joining a frat is somewhat pitied because much more importance is placed on joining a Harvard Final Club as an upperclassman.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: Athletics aren't all encompassing for student life—the football team doesn't rule the school—but they do provide a strong focal point for school spirit and community, especially through our rivalry with Yale.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: Greek life is very low at Harvard. It is not a main priority for many students but it is available for those who wish to get involved.
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: There is very limited school spirit when it comes to athletics
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: I don't really know a lot about it, the two groups pretty much keep to themselves
Student%20Life.Author: College Senior

Student%20Life.Review: Athletics are popular, especially the Harvard-Yale Game
Student%20Life.Author: College Senior

Student%20Life.Review: Harvard leans on the side of being too liberal, where more moderate opinions can sometimes feel stifled.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: Greek life seems great because if you want to join you can, and if you don't, you aren't bothered by it. It's a part of campus, but a quiet one which is both accessible and ignorable.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: Athletics are perfect. They are a part of the campus, but not central to the campus. Athletes are as focused on their studies as anybody else. It's a fun sideshow -- but nothing more, nor should it be.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: I have no experience with Greek life.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: Greek life is kind of small. Not many frats or sororities, and students involved in Greek life aren't viewed differently as those not involved in Greek life.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: Pretty good athletics. There are a lot of varsity athletes and club athletes, but the events aren't attended by a lot of fans for the most part.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: Harvard-Yale football game is the most important sporting event but most people don't attend the others.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: We have really good football and basketball teams. I don't know much about the other sports but most people support our sports teams. As you can imagine, not everybody at Harvard is into sports..
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: Somewhat strict, but overall the administration is very fair.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: Never met anyone interested in school athletics here
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: Haven't seen any issues myself but seems to be not a problem
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: I really have no interaction with Greek life on campus
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: The administration is very helpful here. There is always somebody to lend an ear or be of any support.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: We have order and discipline
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: Every rule and regulation is in place not to punish students if they get caught, but to make sure they're safe despite their decisions.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: HUPD officers are awesome - they genuinely want to protect students, not ruin their fun. They also want to get to know the students. I even had several HUPD officers sing me an enthusiastic "Happy Birthday" on my birthday, and I often stop and have conversations with them around campus. Generally, the administration at Harvard takes a pretty lenient position on disciplining students. I was busted twice by my proctor for having alcohol in my dorm room as a freshman, and nothing happened; he didn't even write down the offenses for records. This is the general attitude of most administrators toward alcohol, marijuana, and noise violations.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: Few people realize that all of Harvard's varsity sports are Division I and that Harvard has the largest varsity sports program in the country in terms of number of sports and number of athletes. That being said, athletics aren't one of the most important aspects of the Harvard scene. There's a reason why all sporting events are free for undergraduates. Most students go to a least a few home games, but you may see students doing their homework in the stadium. However, the Harvard-Yale football game ("The Game") is one of the biggest events of the year for students, alumni, faculty, and administrators. Everyone goes to The Game every single year, and everyone has an awesome time.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: I'm in one of the four sororities on campus, and honestly I don't consider a very important aspect of my college experience. None of the Greek organizations are officially recognized by the university, and none of the sororities even have houses. Very, very few students live in the frat houses; the houses are mostly used for parties. While it's nice to forge connections and friendships with students from different years with different interests, Greek life doesn't play a huge role in the social scene at Harvard. Male final clubs are far more popular, and their parties are better-attended.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: The only downside that can be stated is that Harvard does not excel in "popular" sports. Football, soccer, etc. are pretty mediocre when compared to the rest of the country. However, we are generally top in our league, and the basketball team has participated and made a good showing in March Madness several times now. Furthermore, if niche sports are your thing, you can't beat Harvard. The crew, squash, and sailing teams are often world renowned and compete internationally. The athletic facilities are also fairly state of the art and gorgeous.
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: Harvard gets a bad rap for being "stuck up" or "snooty," but when I hear that, I want to question who that person has chosen to hang out with. Yes, there can be a WASPy vibe at the finals clubs, but if that is not your scene, there are countless other options. The girls can be preppy, and there is an over abundance of vineyard vine items, but it is more a factor of being in New England, rather than Boston.
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: Harvard does a great job of investing in a diverse student body, very supportive of other sexualities and strong vocal presence of minorities.
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: There are about three small frats and three sororities on campus. Not much else to say about that...
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: Harvard guys are a bit of a conundrum.  Relationships aren't really a thing here.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: I would say Harvard isn't too strict about alcohol use.  Freshmen aren't allowed to have alcohol in their dorms, but it's give or take whether or not parties that happen get busted/the host(s) get into trouble.  In the Houses, parties are free to occur so long as they don't create extreme amounts of noise, and varies depending on the proctor living in the dorm.  Harvard hates when its students protest though.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: Harvard is an extremely diverse place in terms of race, background, economic status, sexual orientation, country of origin, all that stuff. People here tend to have a unique perspective and something that they contribute to the community around them.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: I've never encountered any problems.  Freshman parties get broken up every so often if they are noisy.  Basically you have to do something really bad and stupid to get in any real trouble.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: Harvard is interesting - not the ugly-nerd stereotype many expect.  We have world-class athletes and rich legacy kids, which definitely contribute to overall attractiveness, but also i've found that smart people are much better-looking than i expected.  Overall, the students are attractive AND smart, interesting, and put-together.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: There are 4 sororities & 4 fraternities.  Great alternatives to the final clubs if you are interested in joining a social group.  The frats have parties.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: It's nice that it isn't the only important thing here, but the spirit and athleticism is definitely apparent.  We have great facilities and world-class athletes.  I have several friends who either were in the olympics already or are on the fast-track to be in them soon.  Games are fun and well-attended, and club/intramural athletes are well-respected as well.  Sports teams also hold parties regularly :)
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: Very diverse place where most people are open to hearing others' opinions, and actually interested in expanding their own views in an intellectual manner.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: I've never had any problems! If you respect the people around you and yourself neither will you!
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: Look to I, Too, Am Harvard to see how well our school does with racial equality.  Luckily, the conservatives on campus are few and far between.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: People only get excited about sports around Harvard/Yale or the NCAA, but we're decent.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: We are all pretty smart, and fairly good looking. A lot of people like to let everyone know they are smart and can come off as a bit snobbish. But there are also some people out there who don't do that.
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: Depending on if we are talking about academics or social strictness, the rating would change.
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: We don't feel like we are confined when it comes to our social lives. The amnesty policy helps people get help if they need it.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: We have sororities, fraternities, final clubs, and many other clubs that create a diverse social atmosphere on campus. There is also a lot of diversity in fashion, from boho to preppy to edgy.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: There is an incredible amount of diversity at Harvard, a fact that is evident in many of the clubs and organizations devoted to the celebration of such diversity and bringing together or like-minded individuals.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: Harvard consistently does well in the Ivies, and there's always a lot of crimson pride repping at games, especially Harvard-Yale every year.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: Student involvement in athletics is high, but athletics aren't a big part of campus life. At times, school spirit is lacking.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: The administration is more than fair. They are more concerned with the safety and well-being of the student body.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: Overall, the student body is very accepting and tolerant. But, like anywhere else, there are always exceptions and sometimes those exceptions are very vocal.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: There are students from all over and everyone is pretty respectful.
Student%20Life.Author: Recent Alumnus

Student%20Life.Review: No problems, even with underage drinking. Use common sense.
Student%20Life.Author: Recent Alumnus

Student%20Life.Review: Harvard's Greek presence is small but growing. Many organizations don't have their own housing, which makes it hard to achieve the Greek culture that exists on other campuses.
Student%20Life.Author: Recent Alumnus

Student%20Life.Review: People are pretty accepting. there are many different people
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: HUPD is literally the best thing on the planet. Literally everyone wants to hang out with HUPD. They're all super nice, funny, willing to help. The Amnesty Policy is amazing — if you or a friend has over-imbibed, you can take them to UHS or call HUPD to take care of them with no risk of getting in trouble. Goes to show that student safety takes priority over needless disciplinary action.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: Wicked diverse. Everyone has a different background. Obviously you're gonna get the waspy New Englanders and SoCal kids, but that's part of the diversity.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: Somehow, Harvard's sports are kinda sick. Crew is perennial national champs, basketball is killin it, squash is ridiculous, football is Ivy League champs — not bad at all. Lots of fun to attend the big events (e.g. Harvard-Yale football game, squash nationals, Head of the Charles, etc.). Facilities are wicked nice and under constant renovation to make them nicer.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: Harvard is super diverse. Just my group of close friends comes from all over the US and several different foreign countries. Everyone is pretty accepting of each other, and willing to learn from other people's viewpoints instead of putting them down when they disagree.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: We're division 1, but varsity sports don't rule the school, which I think is a good thing. I don't know much about the club sports but I think the intramurals get big after freshman year. There are several gyms available for anyone to use (I use the law school gym for example) and they're really nice, with great hours.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: We arent a big athletic school like USC but we do have great varsity facilities that are world renowned. I mean just google Harvard Stadium and gape in awe.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: You will meet fascinating people from all over the world. You will learn so much from them in addition to great classes.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: We do not have Frats or sorority houses but have groups of people that belong to them. We also have these things called Final Clubs which are similar. They are male and female final clubs that have a house to socialize and have events but you dont live there. They are pretty exclusive.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: It is better than other schools I have been to
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: People here come from all different backgrounds.  There is a noticeably large number of white, rich, American students, but they are becoming fewer and further between.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: Harvard trusts us.  There are some rules about alcohol in freshman dorms (as long as you aren't loud you're fine), and there is absolutely no supervision in the Houses once you're an upperclassmen.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: The administration is good about enforcing rules that better the community in some shape or form. Drinking isn't allowed in freshman dorms, but they are relatively chill about it in upperclassman dorms. It is very easy to get ahold of alcohol, but the administration makes sure that students know how to do it safely should they choose to or where to go/what to do when things go wrong.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: There's something for everyone, just don't miss hanging out with all the different cool people.
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: Harvard has the resources to makes sure it creates as diverse an environment as possible, and the campus actively works to celebrate, discuss, and accommodate people of all different.
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: Greek life is purely for a dedicated social organization here. They all have their own houses that maybe 6-8 people will live in every semester, but the houses are mainly for hanging out in and partying in. People don't care if you are in the Greek system or not. A lot of people kind of see it as a social system they would never want to be a part of either due to "bro-ness," the idea of essentially paying to hang out with people, or because the Greek system often supports societal systems that they find personally perturbing. Some people also really like the idea of sororities and fraternities. But even with all of that no one cares what you do after you've joined. Everyone I know that's in one is happy with it, and in the end that's all anyone else cares about.
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: Sports here don't matter except for one game a year - The Game. It's the weekend we play against Yale, and literally the entire school goes. When it's at Yale the school provides buses and then entire student body (not to mention several generations of alumni) goes to New Haven for the weekend to tailgate and trash talk. When The Game is at Harvard same thing, but all the Yale students come to our campus.
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: It really depends what crowd you find yourself in. The final club/more social crowd is definitely rated as an "A" but the typical Harvard student is about average.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: Better not get caught with drugs! But drinking strictness is relaxed.
Student%20Life.Author: College Senior

Student%20Life.Review: The Amnesty Policy regarding alcohol is fair if you don't abuse it.
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: The expect us to behave like the adults that we are, and for the most part, it happens
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: Students are polished and ambitious, not to mention well-rounded.
Student%20Life.Author: Recent Alumnus

Student%20Life.Review: I think the policies in place are very fair and upheld in a fair manner as well.
Student%20Life.Author: Recent Alumnus

Student%20Life.Review: The police choose what they want to deal with rather than what they are required to deal with. When it comes to noise control, they don't care. When it comes to gunman on the loose, they are right there. The issue here is that they should care about both.
Student%20Life.Author: College Senior

Student%20Life.Review: Varsity sports at Harvard University are pretty huge, especially the way campus treats us. We have wonderful training and workout facilities, including our own trainers, psychologists, and academic advisers. IM sports are pretty huge, too, because anyone can play. We have some pretty diverse ones, too, though I'm not really sure how popular inner tube water polo is.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: It's strict as a freshman, but as soon as you move out of the yard things become much more lenient. The campus alcohol policy is fair and the security guards and police are great. It's really just freshman dorms that are really strict.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: There is an amazing amount of diversity at Harvard. This is most likely due to the fact that this is a very well-known university but I have met people from all around the world (my roommates and closest friends are from all corners of the earth such as India, Sri Lanka, Sweden, Tanzania, and much more). Of course the number of international and different ethnicity students don't outnumber the "white american" population. Most of the students, regardless of religion, ethnicity, sexual orientation, political beliefs are open minded about other cultures and also love the amount of diversity that Harvard provides. Harvard also has amazing financial aid support so there are students from so many different economic situations that no one would ever feel isolated due to their economic background.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: Sports Are Just Part of the Picture – Athletes are included in everything on campus and are really just some of the talented people among the students here. They are not seen as super stars, but often they appreciate feeling mainstream.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: Barely Exists – There are 3 sororities and 3 fraternities on campus. None of them have residential houses and one fraternity is the only Greek organization with property in the square. Many of the frats and sororities rent spaces in the square for meetings that barely hold all of the members. They are a good outlet for making new friends and for parties and mixers, however final clubs dominate the social scene more than frats/sororities.
Student%20Life.Author: College Senior

Student%20Life.Review: The great thing about athletics at Harvard is that they do not give out scholarships solely for athletic ability.  Students must excel at academics first, with sports as a worthwhile extracurricular activity which may or may not be varsity.  Physical fitness is stressed on campus, but not as a business which trumps education.  I would prefer that athletic facilites (gyms, tracks, etc.) be more accessible to the wider student body at lower prices, but otherwise, I'm quite happy with the program.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: Fairly Safe People Tend to Be Responsible Enough for Themselves – Stay to the lit paths and be ethical and sensible and you will be fine.
Student%20Life.Author: Recent Alumnus

Student%20Life.Review: Citizens of the World on Campus – Harvard University is able to bring to its campus some of the best students from all over the world.  When I returned for the 30th anniversary of the African American Studies Dept and the Gospel Choir, Kumba Singers, I was surprised to see that the choir started when I was there and a member of predominantly black students now had whites, Asians, blacks and every kind of person singing gospel music.
Student%20Life.Author: Recent Alumnus

Student%20Life.Review: While there are occasional single-incident problems, usually related to social issues rather than direct prejudice or discrimination, Harvard is pretty calm and tolerant of all people from all backgrounds. There's large international student community, and those from the US are from every corner of the country with immensely different backgrounds and circumstances. Over all, a very easy-going environment for any kind of person/background.
Student%20Life.Author: Recent Alumnus

Student%20Life.Review: No Greek, All Elite – There isn't a huge greek life scene, but the social events are dominated by Final Clubs, which throw similar parties involving a lot of drinking and generally expected debauchery!
Student%20Life.Author: Recent Alumnus

Student%20Life.Review: Go Crimson! Sporting events are not particularly well attended, and not all of our teams shine through.  But when they do, we're there!
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: There are definitely plenty of nerds, both guys and girls, but also some very fashionable dressers and people who do seem to care more about looking good for class and parties than studying...
Student%20Life.Author: Recent Alumnus

Student%20Life.Review: really not so bad, just study and don't do dumb things
Student%20Life.Author: College Student

Student%20Life.Review: Getting There – Football and basketball are on the rise this year! Crew and squash are the only teams that consistently do well, though.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: Absolutely phenomenal - Harvard has the money to attract students of all sorts of backgrounds, economic or ethnic, and being with this diverse group of students has really opened my eyes to the different conditions people come from.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: Sports teams get lots of resources (aka money), but the quality of the team and coaches depends a lot on the sport.  Also, the culture of Harvard is that "coolness" depends on things other than athletic prowess, which I think is a shocker for some of the athletes.  Here you're cool if you're smart and successful.  Athletes have to work really hard to get great grades and still keep up with their sports.  We have a great women's hockey team, men's basketball team, crew teams, etc.  Don't come to Harvard for volleyball.  I'm not really familiar with the other sports.  Don't come to Harvard if you want to go pro, but do come if you want to play sports in college and then go into a different profession.
Student%20Life.Author: College Senior

Student%20Life.Review: It's harvard. They want to preserve the pristine campus.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: It's There – It's there, it's fun, it's big, it's successful. That's most students' attitude--acknowledging the existence of sports on campus, but not having enough time to actually participate ( as an athlete or spectator ( unless you're on a team of course, in which case good luck))
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: There are students of almost every race, ethnicity, religion, and background here. As with many schools, a fair amount of students are white, but when walking around campus, you easily all different types of people.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: There are many kinds of sport facilities at Harvard, at campus there are sport courts and students can use them every day. I think it is a great oppurtunity to relax after lessons
Student%20Life.Author: College Student

Student%20Life.Review: Great Niche Sports – Not a big deal here except for the Harvard-Yale Football Game.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: What Should It Matter? Contrary to the stereotype, all Harvard students aren't weak, preppy geeks. It's hard to place a general image on the "typical" girl or guy because the students are so diverse. There are pretty gorgeous girls on campus. Some guys are hot, but most are average or could use improvement. A good percentage are gay, so if you're a straight girl looking for some lovin' you might have to do some digging. In any case, everyone is interesting and has a distinct passion. Most are dedicated to studies, and the parties and drinking will begin Thursday the most. Extracurriculars are given good priority. Great cafes and places to hide in around Harvard Square.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: Finals Clubs – Technically, Greek life is limited to a few off-campus sororities that don't really have a presence in the social scene. However, the Finals Clubs essentially take the place of Greek life. They're pretentious, exclusive (often likened to "good old boys' clubs"), and much-criticized by the feminist groups (they only admit men.) Of course, freshman girls are encouraged to come to parties. I know people who do go to their parties every weekend, but I'd say the majority of the Harvard community doesn't.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: College Is Freedom – Rules and laws are bent and broken with regularity - and few people get hurt
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: Not Enough Spirit – Our teams are quite competitive in a lot of Ivy League sports, but too few students get out to support the teams.
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: Greek life is there, but it's definitely not as prominent as on other campuses. There are about four fraternities and three sororities. There is only one frat house. "Final Clubs" dominate our party scene, which are similar to fraternities but are much older and more pretentious.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: Harvard's greatest asset is its people. Students and faculty represent every race, ethnicity, creed - I have met so many people that I would never have met if I stayed in my small town!
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: So and So – People got in here for their brains, not beauty. The 10% of students who are wealthy legacies or athletes tend to look very attractive, but the vast majority are average to ugly. The few bombshells are invariably shallow and conceited, as well as remarkably vapid.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: Girls Are Bad – It is hard to find a good looking girl who can hold a conversation
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: Very Integrated Compared to Other Schools. Students come from all socio economic backrounds and all parts of the world
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: Parties Are Go, School's Not a Game – The Administrative Board, the entity that currently determines the fate of students not meeting academic standards or otherwise breaking campus rules, can be kind of shady, but that's currently going under review. Parties need to be registered in advance, but an unregistered party will just get shut down without any real consequences. Theoretically underage drinking can be punished, but this is usually enforced mainly in the freshman dorms. There's also an amnesty policy at the University hospital so that drunk students and their friends who go there for help won't get into any disciplinary trouble for it. The most important thing is just not to do anything academically dishonest and try to keep your grades up, because the Ad Board nearly always tells a student being disciplined to take a year off (and work/do something deep while on leave).
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: Not Bad, but No Attention – Within the Ivy League, Harvard does very well for itself. That said, it's not a sports-oriented school, and compared to other universities is definitely the small fish in the ocean. The one big sports event that brings everyone together is the Harvard/Yale football game. Other than that, it's pretty rare for a sports event to get much attention from the student body at large.
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: You have the best of the best here all leaders in there field that are doing incredible things. You also have endless options of what you want to do and study.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Professors are always experts in their field and the TAs are super helpful and kind as well.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The academics are absolutely fantastic. They vary, of course, depending on student choice. Many students take only bland huge introductory lecture classes and then complain about how they've never met their professors. However, there are literally thousands of options of the beaten path for small seminar classes in countless areas. I have tried to take as many of these as possible, and my average class size has been about five. Going to dinner at professors' houses is not uncommon, and the vast majority of professors put a lot of time into getting to know students. Every professor holds generous office hours, so any complaint that professors are inaccessible generally rests with the student. After my two-person class last year, which often went hours over, we sometimes went for drinks. Students and professors seem to be parts of the same community, not separate entities. I highly recommend putting at least two small and obscure classes on your schedule every term. Overall, Harvard's academics lives up to its name.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I'm learning about relevant topics.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Tough academics that really push you. The workload depends on what classes you take, but generally, the workload can be pretty heavy. Shopping week for actually being able to sit in on classes before you register for them is really useful.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Great internship opportunities, excellent course availability.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: No select criteria per major, everyone just applies to the college.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: The classes can be small seminars or large lectures, depending on your preference, as both are offered. The professors are incredible and you rarely meet one who is not interested in actually teaching and getting to know you. Office hours are a must. The work load is generally quite manageable and rarely will you find that you actually need to do all the reading assigned; this varies major to major though.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: The government major is one of the largest offered on campus and there is a plethora of resources available and no shortage of classes. I have never not gotten into a class I have truly wanted; often begging a professor is all it takes if you miss the lottery. The work load is not too bad, as long as you accept that you will never do all the readings. And the professors do not expect you to - literally! I have had professors actually say that you should pick the more important readings and start from there. What makes this major amazing at Harvard is the availability of graduate classes to the undergrads, with access to both the law school and the Kennedy school of government.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Amazing professors, great variety of classes to take.  The classes are quite hard, and despite claims that everyone here gets an A, you have to work diligently in order to do well.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: If you major in humanities you automatically get more attention because not many people major in humanities. Most departments are small and friendly.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Special concentrations and are plethora of libraries are two of my favorite academic offerings.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Tons! although there are lots of requirements for each one
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: You don't have to apply like at other schools.  You just choose, unless you're doing social studies.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: It's Harvard.  Everything you could dream of is here if you look for it and aren't afraid to ask.  It can be difficult but so worthwhile.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: It's Harvard... and it lives up to its reputation 100%
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Super easy to switch between majors. I love it!
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I have not been in an internship yet but there are plenty of opportunities and i have heard nothing but great things from other people who have taken internships.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The program is small but caring, and the courses are diverse and informative.  There is much to be done about accommodations for students with underlying disabilities/illnesses.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I have actually just been accepted to study abroad through Harvard. They offer programs in Scandanavia, Japan, Italy, etc. and provide a diverse curriculum in all. Economics is a very popular concentration, as well as Government and Psychology.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: There are very diverse majors offered, however, other majors like business management or supply chain and logistics for example that might translate directly to the job field are not offered.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: No admissions criteria. Just be interested in the subject.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: East Asian Studies is a strong program at Harvard. The language classes were amazing and the course offerings were varied and broad.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: It not only offers the intellectual stimulation I am looking for, it offers courses taught by Harvard professors that are looking to expand their students minds.  It is the stepping-stone I need in order to reach my goal of someday becoming the excellent doctor I hope to be.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: There is an unlimited availability of all areas of academics. The world is open to you for whatever.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: It is Harvard. Being world-renowned is no joke.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I love all of my professors and classes, and my workload is DEFINITELY manageable -- if you were near the top of your class in high school (which most people here were) then you will, for the most part, have enough time to do your work.  There is definitely more work here than in high school (and I went to a pretty competitive high school), but you're in class for so many fewer hours that it's not so bad.  It's all about time management. One problem with classes here is that many big classes are taught by TF's (our version of TA's), so it can be hard to get face time with the professor.  Once you get to upper level classes, however, class size shrinks dramatically.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Harvard's academics are the best. Shopping Period is great.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review:
I'm a Joint Major
The East Asian Studies department is perhaps the top in the country. They have the largest collection of literature on East Asia outside of the Asian continent. They have anything ranging from obscure Chinese films from the 1920's to original scrolls from the Ming Dynasty, to modern Japanese anime. Workload can be heavy but manageable, and it's always with really knowledgeable and passionate professors. The Mandarin language classes are really far away. 

The Social Anthropology department is also pretty good. A few classes can be a little aggravatingly unstructured or ambiguous in nature, but without fail the professor will be interesting and fantastic. Also all of the teachers have written some of the most popular ethnographic texts of our time.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: It has been rated the top academic university in the world since ARWU started ranking them.  Academics are the best thing about Harvard.  People envy the class registration / shopping period process.  Classes are rigorous.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I'm an econ concentrator and there are complaints about that department since it's so big and students get lost in it.  But internships and post-college jobs are very gettable.  Academic advising at Harvard is great.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Academics at Harvard are excellent. The work is challening and demanding even for exceptionally well prepared students. It is not a place for the the feint of heart.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Extremely difficult program, but taught by world leaders in their respective fields.
Academics.Author: College Student

Academics.Review: While the academics are certainly very challenging, I feel that I can hold my own in the classes. Even though I didn't have a perfect GPA or perfect SAT score in high school, I still feel prepared and am really getting the most out of my classes.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I've had a few unpaid political internships, which I felt have been great! However, the search for internships each year can always be a bit stressful.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: There are a multitude of concentrations (majors) in as many academic fields as you could imagine! I love that Harvard does not only offer courses in "traditional" fields, but really allows students to find their own niches!
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: While the application itself was very simple (optional essay question, etc.), the idea of applying to Harvard was, in itself, a bit stressful. Other than that, I don't think I encountered any obstacles in the application process...it's all about sending in your application and crossing your fingers!
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The academics are great with the professors being top-notch. Workload can vary from class to class, but is manageable overall.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The professors are top-notch, oftentimes, however, classes are very large and teaching fellows can vary in quality.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Although there is a lot of work, you learn so much in such a short period of time.  The professors are world class and most are really great lecturers and teachers.  Everybody loves whatever major they choose, because they are all great.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I am thrilled I was accepted to Harvard.  Now the work begins and I am looking forward to that but concerned about financing one year of school.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review:
The process of applying for admission to Harvard University was easy. 
What made the process easy was my resume/application which I have 
been "building" since my undergraduate work and job experience. 
Applying to a school has not been a single action, it has been years of 
studying, receiving awards, job experience and so on.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: I have not arrived at Harvard University yet to begin my studies but having a specific program is necessary to my occupation as an educator.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: I have already had a student internship at the University of Wisconsin Madison which was successful.  My job experience has included five years of teaching music and I am ready to study educational policy and earn a masters degree.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Unparalleled. Incredibly talented professors and students. Very rigorous, but definitely doable if you manage your time appropriately.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Harvard is at the forefront of the field of economics in every way. 7 of the top 24 most cited economists in the world are on the staff, and if you want to you can attend lectures by and even speak to any one of them. As a freshman I had a small seminar with a former chair of the council of Economic Advisors to President Bush (the 21st ranked economist in the world by citations), and Harvard advanced intermediate courses (1011a and 1011b) are among the most difficult and advanced in the country for Sophomores. Harvard is candyland for aspiring economists.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review:
World Class professors, classmates, resources, and facilities. However, it is easy to get through Harvard taking easy classes and not challenging yourself. It is very easy to get a B+ and difficult to get an A or a C. 
Harvard College is a liberal arts undergraduate program, meaning there is no business, marketing, communications, accounting, finance major or concentration. There are a diversity of programs and the option for independent or special concentrations if a subject area isn't available. (One noticeably absent undergraduate concentration is Urban Planning or Architecture and this is usually a "special concentration" based on Graduate School of Design classes). The graduate schools are a great resource for undergrads, and you can take classes at many of them as an upperclassman.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: A Pretty Standard System of Major Declaration – Each student declares majors at the end of the fall semester of sophomore year by submitting an application and coming up with a class schedule for the next two and a half years.  I have never heard of one of these applications being turned down, and in the event that your essay or schedule leaves something to be desired, they will work with you to improve it.  I would suggest getting advice from members of the department beforehand to avoid that kind of hassle later on.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: A Great Network of Connections Opens up Some Amazing Internship Opportunities – As a rising sophomore, I have not yet experienced an internship through Harvard, however their well-connected alumni network is well know to give some incredible internships to Harvard students.  While rising sophomore internships (the summer before sophomore year) are largely unpaid, most students are usually able to later procure paid internships.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Excellent Experience – Holistic, totally involved experience with the top students and professors in the world.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: African American Studies 40 Years Ago – I entered Harvard University in 1969, after Martin Luther King, Jr. had been assassinated that spring. Our class had the largest number of African American students up to that point.  Our demonstrations led to the establishment of the African American Studies Dept.  I majored in this this department with its emphasis on both African and African American history, politics, sociology and literature.  The Harvard/Radcliffe African American Cultural Center was established at the same time as the Department, and provided a summer job for me the summer after my junior year.  I have only revisited Harvard once since I graduated for the occasion of the 30th anniversary of the Department.  I am sure much has changed in the interim.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Poor felicities in semiconductor labs. Most of the terminals were always occupied. You have to make prior appointment for getting a terminal and that too lasted for just one hour.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Visual Arts Dept. Has a Lot of Perks – Being a Visual Arts major at Harvard has its good and bad parts.  The best part is that all of the art supplies that you use in the class are provided and completely FREE! Also, if you are a senior, the department covers the costs of producing your thesis.  No other art school that I know of provides free supplies or thesis funding. Your classroom is your studio space which can be used any day of the week, which is also a plus.  The classes are small in size (no more than 12 students), but this also means that it's hard to secure a spot in them.  The department is very small, which gives it a personal feel, but is also limiting in the choices of courses offered, and the range of art techniques taught.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Foreign Languages – The foreign languages at Harvard are beyond excellent. The faculty are very well qualified, and the 1:1 attention is truly amazing. Students also really enjoy the courses and gain confidence in speaking the language to native speakers.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: What You Would Expect – Way too many courses to fathom. Students are very competitive. Classes are hard not because the material is hard but because everyone else is studying very hard. If you want to learn, this is the place. Just be ready to study...a lot.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Very Competitive. Teachers are usually great. Great discussion of course material through mandatory discussion section for each class. Grading can be a bit harsh.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: It's What You Expect – I'm a science concentrator and pre-med, so my workload is pretty heavy. But I expected that because I go to Harvard. However, it's not difficult to find classes that are easy and interesting. Students have access to their professors (who teach the classes by the way) and TFs. All teaching staff provide students with support and help when asked for.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Academics at Harvard are of the highest caliber. Because of the General Education program, I take courses from a wide variety of fields, and all of my professors have been awesome. The Q-guide (a compilation of student evaluations of courses) is super helpful in choosing classes. Also, we have a week of shopping period every semester where we get to try out any classes we want before registering for them. I've had the opportunity to be a pre-med English concentrator (majors are called concentrations here) - Harvard affords the opportunity to get a great education in any field and prepares you well for any career.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: It's Alright. Heavy workload. Decent faculty interaction. Great facilities and work opportunities. The student center does not exist though.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: That's What I Came for – People already know that Harvard stands for academic excellence, but what most generally don't know is that the academic support system here is designed to make sure that you get the most out of your time here. Professors are not only the best in their fields, but most of them are more than willing to talk to you outside of class and work with you on independent projects.
